title: Winston-Salem Police continue partnerships to combat gun violence
text:
Hide Transcript Show Transcript

>> THANK YOU. LOCAL DEPUTIES AND OFFICERS SAY THEY WANT 2020 TO BE A FRESH START. THEY ARE HOPING THAT CONTINUING PROGRAMS WILL HELP THEM TACKLE GUN VIOLENCE. WE EXPLAIN HOW FORSYTH COUNTY LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS ARE HOPING YOU WILL JOIN IN. REPORTER: LAST YEAR THE WINSTON-SALEM POLICE DEPARTMENT SEIZED 900 GUNS. SO FAR THEY HAVE SEIZED 19, WHICH IS ON TRACK TO SEIZIG HUNDREDS OF MORE BY THE END OF THE YEAR. IN 2019, THE CITY OF WINSTON-SALEM HAD 31 HOMICIDES. SOME VICTIMS WERE TEENAGERS. >> FROM AUGUST TO DECEMBER OF 2019 WE LOST THREE CHILDREN OUT OF OUR SCHOOLS. IT’S TIME TO END THAT. REPORTER: IN HOPES OF A BETTER YEAR, THE POLICE DEPARTMENT WILL CONTINUE ITS PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL AND FEDERAL AGENCIES TO CRACK DOWN ON GANG AND GUN VIOLENCE. >> WE ARE INVESTED IN THE SUCCESS OF PROGRAMS WHERE WE USE TECHNOLOGY TO TRY TO IDENTIFY THE HOT SHOOTER S AND IDENTIFY THE PEOPLE WHO ARE TERRORIZING OUR NEIGHBORHOODS. REPORTER: WHILE LAW ENFORCEMENT ON ALL LEVELS ARE WORKING TO COMBAT THE ISSUE STRATEGICALLY, THEY HOPE THE COMMUNITY WILL ALSO STEP UP TO HELP. >> CONNECT WITH SOME OF OUR NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION, SMART START AND ASK HOW CAN YOU BE INVOLVED WITH READING TO OUR YOUNG CHILDREN SO THAT WE CAN ADDRESS THE LITERACY ISSUE HERE IN OUR COMMUNITY. REACH OUT TO THE SCHOOL SYSTEM AND DR. HAIRSTON. AND FIND OUT HOW YOU CAN MENTOR A CHILD. REPORTER: CHIEF JOHNSON WANTS TO REMIND THOSE WHO OWN A GUN TO KEEP THEM LOCKED UP. SHE SAYS THEY SEE A LOT OF CAR BREAK-IN

Advertisement ‘We’re the biggest gang in this town:' Winston-Salem police share vision to reduce gun crime Share Shares Copy Link Copy

Winston-Salem police hope 2020 is the year they can truly crack down on gun violence. In order to do that, the department said it will continue to work on partnerships with local and federal agencies.“From August to December of 2019, we lost three children out of our schools. It’s time to end that. We have to work together as a community to bring about the change that is needed,” police Chief Catrina Thompson said. In 2019, the City of Winston-Salem had a total of 31 homicides. “Our message is simple. To those who are committing violent crimes in our community, we want to say to you that it will not be tolerated, and we will do everything that we can to stop you,” Council member James Taylor said. Thompson said in order to see change, the partnerships between local and federal agencies need to continue in 2020.“You have to have resources -- federal, state, local and community -- in order to be able get after the root causes of violence and those who are committing violent crimes,” said Matt Martin, U.S. Attorney for the Middle District of North Carolina. “We’re invested in the success of programs like Nibin, where we are using technology to try to identify the hot shooters, to try to identify the people who are terrorizing our neighborhoods. We’re using things like notifications like the chief mentioned through our Project Safe Neighborhoods program to try to give people the dignity of a choice. You want to commit violence? You’ve committed violence in the past? Well, that stops now because you’re on our radar screen and you have a choice.”Through various partnerships and programs, the police department hopes to crack down on gang and gun violence in the community. “Our hope is that by doing this we can get out in front of these crimes and stop them before they happen. That is the goal and mission of ATF and we’re proud to be a part of this effort here in Winston-Salem,” an ATF agent said. Thompson said law enforcement cannot do it on its own; they need help from the community. “Connect with some of our nonprofit organizations like Smart Start and ask how you can be involved with reading to our young children so that we can address the literacy issue here in our community. Reach out to the school system and Dr. Hairston and find out how you can mentor a child, how you can adopt a school or classroom to help with our children,” Thompson said. “Gangs are providing things to our children that they figure they need and are not getting in life. As parents, as community leaders, as law enforcement, we’re the biggest gang in this town and we need to take charge of instilling hope in our children. A child without hope is a child living in danger.”Thompson said in 2018, the department sized more than 680 firearms. In 2019, she said, they seized 900. So far this year, they have seized 19 guns, which she said is on track to seizing hundreds of more guns by the end of 2020.Thompson wants to remind those who own guns to lock them up correctly, so they do not end up in the wrong hands. “We have people who are in lawful possession of guns, leaving them inside of locked vehicles unsecured. Somebody comes in, breaks into the vehicle and now we have a gun on the street that’s being used to offend against our citizens,” Thompson said.
meta_description: Winston-Salem police hope 2020 is the year they can truly crack down on gun violence. In order to do that, the department said it will continue to work on partnerships with local and federal agencies.
